hints.content: Start by understanding the operation that needs to be performed on the string. You will take pairs of consecutive digits and compute their sum modulo 10.
Remember that the length of the string reduces by 1 after each operation. If the string starts with n digits, it will take n-2 operations to reduce it to 2 digits.
Consider how you will iterate through the string to compute the new digits. You will need to use a loop to access each pair of digits.
When calculating the new digit from a pair, ensure you are correctly converting the characters to integers. Use `int(s[i])` to convert a character to its integer value.
After calculating the new digits, think about how to store them. You might want to use a list to hold the new digits before converting it back to a string.
As you perform the operations, keep track of the length of the string. You will stop when the length is exactly 2.
Pay attention to the final two digits of the string. Your result should be true if they are equal and false otherwise.
Consider edge cases, such as when the input string has exactly 3 digits. What will happen in that case after the first operation?
Think about how you can optimize your approach. Since the operations are repetitive, can you find a pattern or a way to reduce the number of operations?
Make sure to handle the conversion back to a string correctly. After each operation, you will need to convert your list of digits back to a string.
Remember to check the constraints provided in the problem. The string will always have a length between 3 and 100,000.
You might want to implement a helper function to perform the digit summation operation. This can make your code cleaner and easier to understand.
Debugging will be crucial. Print the intermediate results after each operation to ensure that the transformations are happening as expected.
Consider using a while loop that continues until the length of the string is 2, and within that loop, perform the digit summation.
Finally, after reducing the string to 2 digits, compare them directly. You can use a simple equality check to return the result.

questionNotes: The string consists only of digits (0-9).
The operations reduce the string length by 1 each time.
The final output is a boolean indicating if the last two digits are equal.
